text: it's Park Queens Here I am on my way to
a rehearsal of the Thai royal barque
procession I am an honored guest today
and I'm looking forward to it it's going
to be a great opportunity to see pie
culture
prior to the ceremony we were treated to
a spectacular feast that included duck
garnished with fried Ivy gourd leaves
and my personal favorite dish the deep
fried soft-shell crab we just arrived to
the navy grounds here in bangkok getting
ready to watch the barges as they pass
by got about a couple hours till they
pass so now just kind of hanging out and

normally a choppy water highway

Oh
the royal barge procession which has
been a ceremony for over 700 years first
began during Thailand's Ayutthaya period
the fleet of barges includes 52 boats
which are rowed by a total of 2311
oarsmen the arrangement of the
procession is based on an ancient battle
formation five columns across the river
that span 1200 meters in length the
Royal chant which was composed solely
for the royal barge procession is an
essential component of the ceremony the
soothing chant is synchronized to the
rowing pattern boats are incredibly
elaborate they're coming through the
first phase already came through and I
think there might be some some more
boats that are still coming through but
it really is a peaceful and amazing
thing to witness
there are four main golden barges each
unique and ornately designed the Royal
Golden Swan barge one of the most
spectacular in the fleet was carved from
a single trunk of teak wood and measures
forty four point nine meters in length
the royal barge possession is an
incredible glimpse at the traditional
culture of Thailand and a remarkable
preservation of craftsmanship and
heritage the boat procession has just
ended it took all in all it took about
15 minutes and I would have to say that
it was extremely well done the boats
were truly magical and the the whole
procession the the rowing techniques and
the costumes it was a very incredible
sight to see
